questions.text: A patient with massive bleeding presents to the emergency after RTA. What still needs to be done?

options.label: C
options.text: IV crystalloid 2 L within a few minutes

questions.correct_answer: C. IV crystalloid 2 L within a few minutes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV crystalloid 2 L within a few minutes Avoid dilutional coagulopathy by avoiding clear fluids (crystalloids or colloids) and by giving a transfusion that approximates whole blood – usually administered as equal volumes of packed red blood cells and plasma. In fluid deficit management, a bolus dose of 1 L of lukewarm isotonic crystalline fluid is the standard protocol. Various studies have concluded that infusion more than 1.5 L isotonic crystalline fluid increases mortality. Early control of external bleeding is vital in managing the injured patient.

Highyeild:

Damage Control Resuscitation Damage control resuscitation (DCR), also known as hemostatic resuscitation, is a paradigm that prioritizes hemorrhage control in patients who are still actively bleeding. The rationale is that no aspect of the shock state – end­ organ perfusion, blood pressure, temperature, lactic acidosis – can be corrected while patients are bleeding, and repeated cycles of volume resuscitation will exacerbate coagulopathy, hypothermia and metabolic derangements (acidosis, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia). DCR applies only while patients are bleeding and is based on four key principles Rapid hemorrhage control Permissive hypotension Avoiding dilutional coagulopathy Treating existing coagulation deficits

questions.text: Which flap-based procedure is used for pilonidal sinus surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rhomboid Pilonidal flap sinus Pilonidal sinus describes a condition found in the natal cleft near the coccyx, consisting of single or multiple noninfected in the midline. It is commonly seen in jeep drivers. Therefore, it is also called Jeeper’s bottom, mainly seen at the gluteal cleft. Seen at a young age: 20–29 years. It is present in the interdigital cleft in the hands of a hairdresser, also seen in the umbilicus and axilla. Recurrence rate is very high after surgery. Excision of all tracks and closure by other means designed to avoid a midline wound (Z-plasty, Karydakis procedure, and Limberg’s flap). Bascom’s procedure involves an incision lateral to the midline to access the sinus cavity, which removes hair and granulation tissue. Flaps and Uses Rhomboid flap For cheek, temple, back, and flat surface defects Transposition flap The most basic design, leaving a graftable donor site Advancement flap For flexor surfaces; may need triangles excised at the base to make it work (commonly called Burow’s triangles) Z-plasty For lengthening scars or tissues Bilobed flap For convex surfaces, especially the nose Rotation flap For convex surfaces V-to-Y advancement Commonly used for fingertips and extremities Bipedicle flap For eyelids, rarely elsewhere

questions.text: A patient had a road traffic accident and was put on mechanical ventilation. He is opening his eyes on verbal commands and can move all four limbs spontaneously. What will be his GCS score?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10 Ideally it should have been 9. NT according to the new update, but this question was based on the old concept of the verbal score being considered as one in an intubated patient. So the answer is 9T or 10.

Highyeild:

Glasgow Coma Scale Score: The initial assessment of the trauma patient includes the primary survey, resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care. Neurosurgical evaluation begins during the primary survey with the determination of the GCS score (usually referred to simply as the GCS) for the patient. The GCS is determined by adding the scores of the best responses of the patient in each of the three categories. The motor score ranges from 1 to 6, verbal from 1 to 5, and eyes from 1 to 4. The GCS, therefore, ranges from 3 to 15 Tracheal intubation or severe facial or eye swelling can impede verbal and eye responses. In these circumstances, the patient is given a score of 1 with a modifier, such as verbal “1T” where T = tube

questions.text: While doing an emergency laparotomy for intestinal obstruction, which organ will you first visualize to say whether it is small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cecum Cecum is always the first structure that should be seen in bowel obstruction. If it is dilated, it suggests significant bowel obstruction, whereas if it is collapsed, it signifies small bowel obstruction.

Highyeild:

Radiological features of obstruction (on plain x-ray) The obstructed small bowel is characterized by straight segments that are generally central and lie transversely. No/ minimal gas is seen in the colon The jejunum is characterized by its valvulae conniventes , which pass entirely across the width of the bowel and are regularly spaced, giving a ‘Concertina’ or ladder effect Ileum –Wangensteen has piquantly described the distal ileum as featureless Caecum – a distended caecum is shown by a rounded gas shadow in the right iliac fossa Large bowel , except for the caecum, shows haustral folds , which, unlike valvule conniventes, are spaced irregularly, do not cross the whole diameter of the bowel and do not have indentations placed opposite one another Features of obstruction: In high small bowel obstruction, vomiting occurs early, is profuse and causes rapid dehydration. Distension is minimal with little evidence of dilated small bowel loops on abdominal radiography In low small bowel obstruction; pain is predominant with central distension. Vomiting is delayed. Multiple dilated small bowel loops are seen on radiography In significant bowel obstruction, distension is pronounced. Pain is less severe, and vomiting and dehydration are later features. The colon is proximal to the obstruction and is distended on abdominal radiography. The small bowel will be dilated if the ileocaecal valve is incompetent Small bowel obstruction predominantly has bilious vomiting, whereas it is rare in the large bowel.

Table:

#MANTRA Large bowel obstruction (LBO) can be classified as dynamic (mechanical) or adynamic (pseudo-obstruction). Mechanical obstruction occurs due to blockage of the large bowel, resulting in increased intestinal contractility. Conversely, pseudo-obstruction is characterized by the absence of intestinal contractility, often associated with decreased or absent motility of the small bowel and stomach. Colorectal cancer is the most common cause of LBO , with rectal cancer being more common than sigmoid. Adhesions , which are the most common cause of small bowel obstruction. are rarely a cause of colonic obstruction. In LBO , the colon becomes distended as gas, stool, and liquid accumulate proximal to the site of the blockage. Vascular compromise of the obstructed colon can occur due to excessive enlargement, leading to necrosis and perforation. Clinical features of LBO include failure to pass stool and flatus associated with increasing abdominal distention and cramping abdominal pain. An abdominal X-ray can reveal a distended colon , while a CT scan can help reveal an inflammatory process such as diverticulitis. A water-soluble contrast enema can diagnose suspected cases of volvulus or distal sigmoid cancer. Virtually all patients with complete acute large bowel obstruction require prompt surgical intervention and should not undergo a trial of non-operative management. Acute large bowel obstruction in patients with a competent ileocecal valve is a true surgical emergency because of the high chances of perforation, with the cecum being the most common site. Once the diagnosis has been made, surgical exploration should be undertaken as soon as possible after appropriate resuscitation

questions.text: What is the method of breast examination depicted in the video? (The clinician palpated with the tips of finger except the thumb, started from 2 o’clock posterior palpated at 3 points on the line joining periphery to the nipple. Then again went to 3 o’clock point directly and came back centripetally while palpating at 3 points again on the line joining periphery and nipple):
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clock wise method Clock wise method/ dial of clock method involves palpating the breast segmentally with the pads of the middle three fingers (index, middle, and ring) held in a slightly bowed position. The breast is examined as if it were a "dial of the clock," with the highest point at the upper edge of the breast just below the mid-clavicular point (12 o'clock) and the lowest point at the infra-mammary crease (6 o'clock). Palpation begins at 12 o'clock from the periphery of the breast towards the nipple by describing small circles of approximately 3 cm in diameter. Circular movements of the fingers' pads are made, increasing the pressure without lifting the fingers. The next circle is palpated towards the nipple, overlapping with the previous circle to about half its diameter. Once the areola and nipple area is reached, the next segment/sector is palpated at 1 o'clock. The inner half of the mammary gland is palpated while the patient is in a supine position. The patient is then asked to roll over onto the opposite side to palpate the outer half of the mammary gland. This allows the mammary tissue to fall towards the midline by gravity, resulting in a flattening of the lateral half of the mammary gland, making a lump in the lateral half more discernible.

Highyeild:

Clinical features of the breast cancer Breast cancer may not cause any noticeable symptoms in its early stages. However, some changes in the breast may indicate the possibility of breast cancer, such as a change in the size or shape of the breast, discharge from a single duct, particularly if it is blood-stained , skin dimpling , nipple retraction , and enlargement of axillary nodes . In some cases, breast cancer can cause symptoms that indicate the possibility of metastasis , such as difficulty breathing, bone pain, symptoms of hypercalcemia, abdominal distention, and jaundice . Other features of breast cancer include multifocality , which is the presence of second cancer in the same quadrant, within 4 cm, and multicentricity , which is the presence of second cancer outside the quadrant of the primary cancer, away at least 4 cm. Dimpling and puckering of the skin over the breast are caused by infiltration of the ligament of Cooper by the carcinoma. In rare cases, breast cancer can cause cancer en-cuirasse , which is the infiltration of the breast skin and chest wall with multiple nodules and ulceration by the carcinoma.
